Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Unraveling Molybdenum and Rhenium speciation: Identifying the burial pathways of redox proxies in sulfidic settings
Award.AbstractNarration:
When natural waters become devoid of oxygen, dissolved sulfide is produced and can accumulate via microbial sulfate reduction. Sulfidic conditions occurred within ancient oceans, and lead to extinction events in marine biota. Redox sensitive trace metals, like molybdenum (Mo) and rhenium (Re), display contrasting chemical behavior between oxygenated and sulfidic waters and therefore can be used as tools to enhance our understanding of the Earth's oxygenation history and the evolution of life. Oxygen depletion also occurs within modern oceans, probably as a result of anthropogenically-induced eutrophication. Such conditions have been observed globally, predominately in coastal areas, and have become a major environmental issue leading to massive fish kills. Thus, in addition to providing information on how and when the rise of oxygen (approximately Â­2.4 billion years ago) in Earth's atmosphere facilitated the development of life, Mo and Re can contribute to assessing and preventing the development of oxygen-depleted zones within modern oceans. However, to fully exploit Mo and Re as indicators of oxygen-depleted conditions, the chemical transformations these metals undergo in sulfidic waters must be well defined, as well as the mechanisms governing their ultimate burial. Filling these gaps in knowledge is the backbone of this study as well as the future work it will spawn.

In response, a two-pronged study has been initiated. (1) Quantify actual Mo and Re speciation in natural sulfidic waters utilizing our recently developed chromatographic method (reverse phase ion pair chromatography: RP-IPC). Investigators aim to (a) couple their present RP-IPC method with ICP-MS, (b) utilize RP-IPC-ICP-MS to quantify individual thiomolybdate and thioperrhenate anions in the water column of Green Lake (New York, USA), a lake characterized by a permanent chemocline and (c) quantify any stable Mo or Re isotopic fractionations during transitions among thiomolybdates and thioperrhenates. (2) Survey the role FeMoS cubane clusters play in the ultimate burial of Mo and Re under euxinic conditions. They will (a) produce and analyze solutions comprising an array of initial Fe, Mo, sulfide, ionic strength, and pH conditions as well as trace quantities of Re, and (b) use X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) spectroscopy to characterize any FeMoS solid produced in the test solutions. The impact of this study will extend widely. Five outcomes stand out most clearly: (1) Support the geoscientific community studying biospheric evolution. (2) Provide a new method for quantifying thiometallate speciation and isotopic fractionation. (3) Involve several undergraduate researchers from underrepresented minorities in all facets of the proposed research. (4) Train a Ph.D. student as a part of an international collaboration. (5) Communicate research results at appropriate conferences, as well as submit several scientific articles to disseminate findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molybdenum (Mo) has been used as paleo-redox proxy to investigate the Earth’s oxygenation history and the evolution of life. In modern and ancient sedimentary records, the variations in Mo concentration and isotopic signature have contributed to identify periods of oxygenation or anoxic episodes that coincided with extinction events.

 

Laboratory experiments have demonstrated when sulfide concentrations increase in water, sulfur substitutes progressively for oxygen in MoO42-, leading to the formation of thiomolybdates (MoOxS4-x2-). Although the geoscientific community largely accepts this model, solely based on thermodynamic predictions, actual Mo speciation (i.e., measuring the Mo chemical species present) has never actually been identified or quantified within any natural sulfidic basin because apt methodologies for doing so do not exist. Thus, the role of the thiomolybdates remains speculative.

 

Furthermore, the mechanisms governing Mo burial in sulfidic sediments remain unknown. For example, FeMoS cubane clusters have been conjectured to be responsible for Mo uptake in euxinic waters via a co-precipitation process. Unfortunately, the veracity of this claim has not been demonstrated. These gaps in knowledge impeded the full utility of Mo as a paleo-redox proxy and our understanding of trace metal cycling, in general. To fill these gaps, two main goals were proposed:

 

  1. To quantify actual Mo speciation in natural sulfidic waters using an ion chromatography technique coupled to an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (IC-ICP-MS)
  2. To survey the role FeMoS cubane clusters play in the ultimate burial of Mo under euxinic conditions

 

The following outcomes were successfully achieved:

  1. Develop a new chromatographic method to separate all thiomolybdate species within 30 min
  2. Couple an IC with an ICP-MS to determine Mo speciation in sulfidic waters at natural levels
  3. Measure Mo isotopic fractionations during transitions among thiomolybdates
  4. Propose an updated kinetic model to predict Mo speciation based on Mo isotopes data
  5. Highlight the role of FeMoS cubanes as an important burial pathway for Mo
  6. Characterize Mo speciation in ancient sediments using X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure
  7. Identify two burial pathways of Mo in euxinic sediments: Organic matter and Fe-S minerals

 

In addition to the scientific discoveries, this project contributed:

  1. To support to the geoscientific community studying biospheric evolution by improving one of their most valuable tool (i.e., Mo as a paleo redox proxy).
  2. To provide new methods for determining Mo speciation
  3. To involve several undergraduate researchers in all facets of this research
  4. To train a Ph.D. student in conducting research projects and communicating his results
  5. To disseminate our findings to the society via the publication of several articles and many presentations at international conferences
